name.namePart: auteur d'une seule épigramme satirique, en latin

mads.note: Brill's New Pauly: "Eucheria, Versus Eucheriae poetriae (‘Verses of the poetess E.’) is the title of an epigram in 16 elegiac distichs in the Cod. Paris. Lat. 8071 (Thuaneus; 9th cent.); this text is found, sometimes incomplete and without title, in other codices of the 9th-12th cents. It is a catalogue of monstrous associations of ‘noble’ and ‘base’ objects... the meaning of these associations is clarified in the concluding distichon, which speaks of the absurdity of a man of low birth being a suitor of E. It is conceivable that the name was secondarily interpreted as the poetess' name. The text was probably written about the 5th cent. AD because the masculine form of the name, Eucherius, is well attested in this period...." Smolak, Kurt (Vienna), “Eucheria”, in: Brill’s New Pauly, Antiquity volumes edited by: Hubert Cancik and , Helmuth Schneider. Consulted online on 26 May 2017
